raw_text:
Kennedy predicts bigger turnout
 
 Voters' "pent up passion" could confound predictions of a low turnout in the coming general election, Charles Kennedy has said.
 
 The Liberal Democrat leader predicted concerns over Iraq and other international and domestic issue would express themselves during the campaign. His comments come as an inquiry looks at how best to boost voter turnouts. Ex-foreign secretary Robin Cook said people were not apathetic but fed up of "pager politics" and not being heard. He, like Mr Kennedy, pointed to the hundreds of thousands of people who demonstrated against plans for the Iraq war.
 
 Mr Cook, who is giving evidence to the Power inquiry into voter turnout rates, told BBC Radio 4's Today Programme it was not fair to blame the public who were "more interested in politics than ever before". "They are turned off by the way we do politics in Britain. There's a message there for politicians." He urged politicians to avoid negative campaigning and to "speak more from the heart". "We should be not so afraid to say what we stand for." He also criticised the cult of personality politics: "There's far too much interest in celebrities. "Politics are in danger of becoming another branch of the celebrity industry." The government has tried a number of things in an attempt to boost voter turnout, which fell to 59% in the last general election in 2001. This has included bringing in directly elected mayors to head local authorities and trialling postal voting.
llama3.2:1b: Charles Kennedy predicts bigger turnout due to concerns over issues.
The Liberal Democrat leader believes many voters will express themselves during the campaign, despite previous predictions of low turnout.
Ex-foreign secretary Robin Cook agrees, saying people are fed up with "pager politics" and need to be heard.
Cook urges politicians to avoid negative campaigning and speak more from their hearts.
llama3.2:3b: Charles Kennedy predicts bigger turnout in the coming general election due to voters' "pent up passion" over international and domestic issues, such as Iraq, which he believes would express itself during the campaign, citing hundreds of thousands who demonstrated against the war.
Ex-foreign secretary Robin Cook attributes low voter turnout not to apathy but to frustration with "pager politics" and politicians avoiding negative campaigning.
gemma2:2b: Charles Kennedy predicts high voter turnout fueled by political issues and protests like the Iraq war opposition.
Ex-foreign secretary Robin Cook argues that people are not apathetic but frustrated with politics, calling for more open communication and a shift away from celebrity-based campaigning.
The Power inquiry is investigating methods to boost voter participation after turnout fell in the 2001 general election.
qwen2.5:0.5b: In the upcoming general election, voters' "pent up passion" could lead to a higher turnout, according to Charles Kennedy, who predicts concerns over Iraq and other issues will be expressed during the campaign.

Robin Cook, ex-foreign secretary of Prime Minister Tony Blair's government, criticizes this as a sign that people are not interested in politics as usual, suggesting they prefer not hearing their voices being heard.
He urges politicians to avoid negative campaigning and "speak more from the heart" by acknowledging what they stand for and avoiding celebrity politics.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Charles Kennedy predicts higher turnout due to voters' "pent up passion" influenced by concerns over Iraq and other issues, while Robin Cook criticizes apathy as a facade, suggesting politicians should engage more emotionally and avoid celebrity politics to boost voter participation in the upcoming election.
qwen2.5:3b: Kennedy predicts higher turnout due to voters' pent-up passion regarding international and domestic issues like Iraq.
Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy believes concerns over these topics will manifest during the campaign, contrary to predictions of low turnout.
Former Foreign Secretary Robin Cook emphasizes that people are not apathetic but frustrated by current "pager politics" and lack of voice, citing demonstrations against the Iraq war.
He advises politicians to avoid negative campaigning and emphasize their stances instead of focusing on celebrity culture.
The government has implemented measures like directly elected mayors and postal voting to boost voter turnout, which was at 59% in 2001 general election.

tinyllama:1.1b:
Kennedy predicts bigger turnout due to pent-up passion

Veteran Liberal Democrat politician Charles Kennedy stated that the upcoming general election would likely see a higher vote turnout compared to previous elections.
He cited concerns over Iraq and other international issues as contributing factors, along with an increased appetite for change among voters.
The party leader also called for more positive campaigning and less negative rhetoric from politicians.
Kennedy argued that too much emphasis had been placed on personality politics, which he believed could be a liability in the election's run-up.
tinydolphin:1.1b: A more concise summary: Kennedy suggests that people's pent-up passion could affect turnout during the upcoming election, predicting a higher voter turnout than current numbers suggest.
He attributes this to the concern over Iraq and other global issues.
Cook, a former foreign secretary who took part in demonstrations against the Iraq war, called for more communication, as people are not "apathetic but fed-up of pager politics."
phi:2.7b: Charles Kennedy predicts higher-than-expected voter turnout for upcoming elections, attributing it to people's pent-up passion about international and domestic issues.
Robin Cook agrees that voter apathy is not the cause but instead blames politicians' negative campaigns and the lack of a clear message from them.

Cook urges politicians to avoid negative campaigning and speak more from the heart, while also criticizing the cult of personality politics and the government's efforts to boost turnout, which have been less successful than they hoped.

Robin Cook, ex-foreign secretary, agrees that people are not apathetic but fed up of "pager politics" and not being heard, pointing to the hundreds of thousands of people who demonstrated against plans for the Iraq war.
Mr Cook urged politicians to avoid negative campaigning and speak more from the heart and not be afraid to say what they stand for.
The government has tried a number of things to boost voter turnout, which fell to 59% in the last general election.

granite3.1-dense:2b: Charles Kennedy, Liberal Democrat leader, anticipates increased voter turnout for the upcoming general election due to citizens' "pent-up passion" driven by concerns about Iraq and other global/domestic issues.
